Great video, love the thermal camera.
I think a great demo would be some small scale "runaway reaction" (also called thermal runaway to an engineer) and film it with the thermal camera. Showing the difference in exotherms from microscale to small scale in an exothermic reaction/polymerization (a Grignard is the textbook example of this) . You can explain how exotherms can potentially cause a feedback loop to self propagate and cause "runaway" (maybe a little mention of Trommsdorff Norrish (TDN) if you're feeling crazy)... idk if this will be over people's head but I found this kinda stuff fascinating in graduate school and a thermal camera seems like the perfect way to demonstrate it.

Again, great videos keep up the good work!

Hi Nile. i have an idea for a reaction. It would be fascinating if you could replicate the Fischer–Tropsch reaction for the production of methane at low temperature. I have no idea what the geology is like where you are but doing it using olivine and and a metal catalyst is the method discussed in a few papers that are discussing the non-biological production of methane on Mars.

This is apparently done both at Earth temp/pressure and at Martian temp/pressures, getting a reaction environment to do it under Martian conditions is probably out of scope for a home lab in terms of manipulating the reaction whilst in a simple vacuum vessel.

Replicating the reaction under Earth conditions would be very interesting and could even be classed as progressing the theory of how there is Martian methane as some areas e.g.: in the bottom of craters etc have conditions that are comparable to some condition here on Earth.

Nice video NileRed! I'm an electrical engineer and what you said about thermal imaging being useful for electronics design is very true. One aspect you didn't mention is its ability to find short circuits (like solder problems) very quickly. Thermal cameras can easily see even a 0.1 deg C temperature difference. Traces on a circuit board will rise by more than that when even an amp or two are flowing through them. So, you can find a short circuit by powering up the board with a low current limited power supply and looking at it with the thermal camera.
